questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a self-detected lump in her left breast that she noticed two months ago. She reports no associated pain, nipple discharge, skin changes, or systemic symptoms. She notes that the lump appears more prominent during the week before her period. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any medications. She has no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. She has irregular menstrual cycles and a BMI of 32 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a 3 cm, smooth, mobile, round, and rubbery mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observation and repeat breast examination and imaging in 6 months

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 3 cm smooth, mobile, round, and rubbery mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast without signs of associated infection, nipple retraction, or skin changes. The mass fluctuates with her menstrual cycle. This clinical presentation is suggestive of a fibroadenoma. The best next step in the evaluation of suspected fibroadenoma in a patient younger than 35 years old is an ultrasound of the breast, as it can distinguish fluid-filled cysts from solid masses and characterize these masses as benign or suspicious for malignancy. If the patient is 35 years old or older, breast ultrasound and mammography are both indicated.  

For an adult presenting with a breast mass suggestive of a fibroadenoma, ultrasonography, and mammography are useful in classifying the fibroadenoma as simple, complex, or giant based on distinct radiologic features.    

With a simple fibroadenoma, ultrasonography often depicts a well-circumscribed, uniform, hypoechoic, oval, or round lesion, while mammography may show a well-circumscribed oval mass that is either hypodense or isodense to the surrounding breast tissue. Macrolobulation or partially obscured margins may also be seen. Simple fibroadenomas in young women that are asymptomatic and not enlarging may be followed with a repeat breast exam and imaging studies at 6 months to determine if they continue to be stable, or a core needle biopsy may be performed.  

In ultrasonography, a complex fibroadenoma may exhibit features of a simple fibroadenoma, but will also have internal calcifications, irregular borders, or lobulations. A mammogram often reveals a well-circumscribed oval or round mass with 'popcorn' calcifications, and obscured or irregular borders. An ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy with histopathology revealing sclerosing adenosis, duct epithelial hyperplasia, epithelial microcalcifications, and papillary apocrine changes, along with stromal and glandular elements of fibroadenomas confirms the diagnosis.  

A giant fibroadenoma is typically larger than 5 cm on ultrasound, maintaining the well-circumscribed, uniform hypoechoic characteristics of simple fibroadenomas. Mammography may reveal a large, well-circumscribed mass that is hypodense or isodense to the surrounding breast tissue. It may be macrolobulated or have partially obscured margins. Importantly, giant fibroadenomas may be confused with phyllodes tumors due to their rapid increase in size. An ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy can help differentiate between the two and excision is recommended for giant fibroadenomas. In giant fibroadenomas, hypercellular stroma, epithelial and myoepithelial hyperplasia, and proliferation of stromal and epithelial cells without a leaf-like growth pattern are typically seen.     

Option Analysis

✅ Breast ultrasonography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Observation and repeat breast examination and imaging in 6 months:
Incorrect: If ultrasonography demonstrates findings consistent with a simple fibroadenoma and the patient remains asymptomatic, then observation and repeat examination and imaging in 6 months to ensure stability would be appropriate treatment. However, this patient first needs imaging of the mass.  
❌ Mammography:
Incorrect: A mammogram can identify and characterize breast masses; however, it is typically used for routine breast cancer screening in women older than 40 years or in addition to ultrasound for the evaluation of probable fibroadenomas in women 35 years old or older. It is less sensitive in younger patients due to the increased density of their breast tissue.  
❌ Breast MRI:
Incorrect: Breast MRI is used for breast cancer screening in high-risk patients, such as those with a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation, or for staging and surveillance of known breast cancer. It is not typically used as a first-line diagnostic tool for a benign condition such as a fibroadenoma.  
❌ US-guided core biopsy:
Incorrect: This patient with a palpable breast mass should have imaging performed first before management. Also core biopsy would not be able to differentiate giant fibroadenoma from phyllodes, so excisional biopsy is required for lesions > 5 cm on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic for the evaluation of a breast mass. She mentions that she noticed a lump in her right breast 3 months ago, which is not associated with pain or nipple discharge. Past medical history is unremarkable. She has no history of trauma. On examination, a well-circumscribed, mobile, non-tender mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. Ultrasound reveals a well-circumscribed mass with internal calcifications, and an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy (CNB) reveals sclerosing adenosis, duct epithelial hyperplasia, epithelial microcalcifications, and papillary apocrine changes consistent with the diagnosis of complex fibroadenoma. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Observation and repeat examination and imaging in 6 months
Observation and repeat examination and imaging in 1 year

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a well-circumscribed, mobile, non-tender mass in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast and ultrasound findings of a well-circumscribed mass with internal calcifications. These findings are suggestive of a complex fibroadenoma, which is confirmed with an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy (CNB). In the absence of mass-related symptoms such as pain and discomfort and without evidence of an enlarging mass, observation with repeat examination and imaging in 6 months is appropriate management. In cases where histopathology reveals findings that indicate an increased risk of malignancy, excision biopsy is recommended.    

Biopsy-proven complex fibroadenomas may be managed with observation, repeat examination and imaging, and reassurance. If however, findings on biopsy indicate the chance of future malignancy (i.e. stromal mitosis, stromal overgrowth, nuclear pleomorphism, fragmentation, adipose tissue infiltration) or patients are symptomatic or have enlarging masses, then excision is recommended.    

Ultrasound-guided cryoablation and vacuum-assisted percutaneous excision are less invasive options for removal of fibroadenomas that may be used to treat certain fibroadenomas that do not have evidence of risk for malignancy. They provide better cosmetic outcomes and quicker recovery. These methods are unsuitable for tumors larger than 4 cm or potentially malignant cases based on clinical or pathological findings.  

Option Analysis

✅ Observation and repeat examination and imaging in 6 months:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Simple mastectomy with adjuvant chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Simple mastectomy with adjuvant chemotherapy is indicated in the management of malignant breast tumors. It is not indicated in the management of fibroadenomas.  
❌ Observation and repeat examination and imaging in 1 year:
Incorrect: Initial follow-up of patients with complex fibroadenomas identified with core needle biopsy who are being managed with observation and re-assessment should be at 6 months, not 1 year.  
❌ Radiation therapy:
Incorrect: Radiation therapy is commonly employed in the management of malignant breast tumors. It is not indicated in the management of fibroadenomas.  
❌ No further management is necessary:
Incorrect: Appropriate management of biopsy-confirmed complex fibroadenomas in patients without mass-related symptoms such as pain and discomfort who do not report enlarging masses includes observation and re-assessment within 6 months to ensure stability. If these masses are enlarging, then an excisional biopsy should be performed to rule out malignant potential.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care office due to pain in her right breast, fatigue, and chills. She is four weeks postpartum and currently breastfeeding. Her baby has had difficulty latching on and she often has to use a breast pump to express milk. She has not had recent trauma to her chest and she smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. She has no family history of breast cancer. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. Chapparoned exam reveals a 4.5 cm area of erythema over the inferior portion of the right breast with associated tenderness, warmth, induration, and fluctuance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who is lactating presents with symptoms of breast pain and chills and fatigue. Physical exam shows skin tenderness, warmth, erythema, induration, fluctuance, and fever consistent with a breast abscess. A breast abscess occurs when a bacterial infection within the breast tissue forms a purulent fluid collection.  Breastfeeding significantly increases the risk of developing a breast abscess, and the immediate postpartum period is the most common time for this to occur.

In addition to breastfeeding, other risk factors for a breast abscess include smoking as seen in this patient, malignancy, recent surgery, nipple piercings, tattoos, and immunosuppression (diabetes and HIV).  Breast abscesses and inflammatory breast cancer can have similar presentations, therefore additional workup should always be considered for patients with a suspected abscess who are not lactating and for patients who do not respond to initial management with antibiotics and incision and drainage if warranted.

Tenderness, erythema, warmth, and edema of the breast are common findings with a breast abscess. Purulent discharge may be noted from the surrounding skin or nipple. Induration and fluctuance indicate the presence of a fluid collection. When suspected, ultrasound should be obtained, as failure to diagnose can result in surrounding tissue destruction and potentially sepsis. Infarction and necrosis of the skin may occur with advanced infections. Fever and systemic symptoms are often present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Breast abscess:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Galactocele:
Incorrect: A galactocele refers to a milk-filled cyst within the breast which typically presents as a painless or mildly painful lump without overlying skin changes. Fluid from a galactocele is typically sterile. This patient has findings consistent with an acute bacterial infection including erythema, warmth, induration, and fever.  
❌ Plugged duct:
Incorrect: A plugged duct occurs when milk does not drain properly, causing tenderness and a palpable lump or cord over the affected area without overlying skin changes. This patient has findings consistent with an acute bacterial skin infection including erythema, warmth, induration, and fever.  
❌ Hematoma:
Incorrect: A cutaneous hematoma refers to a collection of blood under the skin usually caused by trauma. This patient is currently lactating, does not report recent trauma, and has signs and systemic symptoms making breast abscess the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Inflammatory breast cancer:
Incorrect: Inflammatory breast cancer can present similarly to a breast abscess and the two may be clinically indistinguishable at initial presentation. However, a breast abscess is more likely in a lactating patient under the age of 30 who has no family history of breast cancer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of five days of breast pain. She recently had her nipples pierced and has noticed foul-smelling drainage from the right nipple. She reports redness and swelling of the right breast that started yesterday. She has not had a fever or chills. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg. Chapparoned examination of the right breast reveals a 4 cm area of tenderness, erythema, and warmth surrounding the areola with associated induration and fullness of the tissue inferiorly. Crusted purulent material is adherent to the nipple ring.  No fluctuance or skin necrosis is present. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the breast and administration of cephalexin
Urgent mammography and administration of intravenous vancomycin
Punch biopsy and administration of oral cephalexin
Removal of the nipple ring and administer topical mupirocin

questions.solution:
This patient presents with unilateral breast tenderness, erythema, warmth, induration, and fullness suggestive of a breast abscess, likely secondary to an infected nipple piercing. When a breast abscess is suspected an ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the size. Empiric antibiotics should be started. In patients without signs and symptoms of systemic toxicity, oral antibiotics like cephalexin can be administered.

Untreated breast abscesses can result in significant tissue destruction and associated morbidity. Ultrasound is the preferred imaging to confirm the presence of fluid when a breast abscess is suspected and to determine the best method of drainage based on the size of the fluid collection. Additional imaging or biopsy may be necessary to rule out inflammatory breast cancer, which can present similarly in patients without an identifiable cause of the breast abscess and for those who don't respond to initial therapy.

Empiric antibiotic therapy is indicated and should not be delayed due to pending imaging.  Initial coverage should target Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species, with consideration for MRSA coverage. Antibiotics should be tailored based on results of the fluid culture. Route of antibiotic administration is guided by the severity of the presenting illness. Oral antibiotics including dicloxacillin, cephalexin, and clindamycin are appropriate initial empiric antibiotics for stable patients without signs of systemic toxicity. Pain management with non-opioid analgesics should be offered as needed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ultrasound of the breast and administration of cephalexin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urgent mammography and administration of intravenous vancomycin:
Incorrect: Workup for breast cancer with mammography should be considered for patients who fail to respond to initial management for a suspected breast abscess or for patients who have no clear cause of the breast abscess. When indicated, mammography should be performed after a course of antibiotics. For this patient with a known source of infection and no signs of systemic toxicity, outpatient antibiotics and incision and drainage are the best initial step in management.  
❌ Punch biopsy and administration of oral cephalexin:
Incorrect: Workup for inflammatory breast cancer should be considered in patients with a likely breast abscess who fail to respond to initial antibiotics and incision and drainage if warranted and for patients without a clear cause of the breast abscess. This patient has a clear source of infection and has not yet been treated, therefore, she should be treated with oral antibiotics and an ultrasound should be performed.  
❌ Surgical consultation:
Incorrect: Surgical consultation may be necessary for drainage of a breast abscess. This patient should first have imaging to determine if a breast abscess is present and should be treated with empiric antibiotics and incision and drainage if warranted.  
❌ Removal of the nipple ring and administer topical mupirocin:
Incorrect: Topical antibiotics are not sufficient treatment for breast abscesses.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the primary care office to review results of an abnormal breast MRI. The patient has been undergoing yearly screening magnetic resonance imaging of the breasts due to a lifetime risk of breast cancer of > 20% with a family history of breast cancer in the patient’s mother at age 45. The MRI showed an enhancing mass within an enlarged duct in the right breast. The patient feels well and has no symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable and the patient’s only medication is an oral contraceptive pill. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Chaperoned physical exam shows no palpable breast masses in either breast. Core biopsy of the mass is performed and shows an intraductal papilloma without atypia. Which of the following additional exam findings would be most consistent with this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has an intraductal papilloma, which is typically benign and forms in the lining of a milk duct. Clear or bloody nipple drainage is commonly seen with breast papillomas. Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor for intraductal papilloma formation.    

A breast papilloma may present as a solitary lesion, which is often posterior to the nipple, or as multiple papillomas, which are typically more peripheral. When five or more papillomas are present within a localized segment of breast tissue, the condition is referred to as papillomatosis, which is more likely to be found bilaterally and has a higher risk of malignancy.    

Nipple discharge is a characteristic finding with breast papillomas and may be bloody or clear. When nipple discharge is present, the patient may note spontaneous drainage. The discharge can be elicited on examination through gentle clockwise pressure applied around the nipple. Occasionally a mass may be palpated, particularly if there are multiple papillomas present. Patients may also be asymptomatic without associated exam findings, and the papilloma is detected incidentally during routine breast imaging. Breast papillomas are typically benign but may contain atypical or malignant cells; therefore, a tissue biopsy should always be performed when a papilloma is suspected, with or without symptoms.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bloody nipple drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Peau d’orange of the breast:
Incorrect: Peau d’orange is a term used to describe the skin of the breast when there is edema with dimpling that resembles the peel of an orange. Peau d’orange is highly suggestive of inflammatory breast cancer. This patient has an intraductal papilloma that is benign and would not cause peau d’orange
❌ Axillary lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Axillary lymphadenopathy is associated with breast pathology, such as mastitis, breast abscess, or breast cancers. If an intraductal papilloma contains malignant cells it may cause axillary lymphadenopathy. This patient’s intraductal papilloma without atypia is benign and would not cause axillary adenopathy.
❌ Striae of the breast:
Incorrect: Striae of the breast may occur for a number of reasons including rapid distention of the breasts during pregnancy or weight gain, thinning of the skin, or with conditions such as Cushing syndrome. An intraductal papilloma would not cause a significant change in the size or skin integrity of the breast and, therefore, would not cause striae.
❌ Tenderness of the breast:
Incorrect: Tenderness of the breast may be caused by a variety of benign and malignant conditions. Intraductal papillomas can occasionally cause mild pain or tenderness but are usually painless and are more commonly associated with nipple discharge.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a two-week history of pain and swelling in her right breast with purulent discharge from the right nipple. She has had three similar episodes in the past year; each was less severe, resolved partially with antibiotics, and did not involve nipple discharge. She completed breastfeeding her youngest child two years ago. She has not had recent trauma to the breast, nipple piercings, or systemic symptoms. There is no family history of breast cancer. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), heart rate is 80/min, blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 17/min. On examination, there is erythema and induration in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast with a tender mass. There is no fluctuance. A small, draining sinus tract is noted in the affected area, with purulent discharge. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of recurrent breast pain, erythema, induration with a palpable mass, and a draining sinus tract with purulent discharge despite previous antibiotics suggests granulomatous mastitis.     

Granulomatous mastitis is a benign chronic inflammatory condition that typically presents in women of childbearing age. Clinically, it is characterized by unilateral breast pain, swelling, and a palpable mass or masses that can be mistaken for malignancy. Unlike typical mastitis, which is acute and often associated with lactation, granulomatous mastitis can recur sporadically with episodes varying in severity. Patients often report fluctuating, localized symptoms, with episodes of exacerbation and partial resolution. Over time, the condition may progress to form sinus tracts, leading to purulent discharge from the nipple or skin overlying the breast.    

Unlike acute infectious mastitis or recurrent mastitis that can be seen in lactating and nonlactating women, granulomatous mastitis is not generally associated with systemic symptoms like fever or malaise unless it is associated with a secondary infection. While it can occur in women who have previously breastfed, it is not limited to the postpartum period and can arise years after lactation has ceased. Its presentation can be variable, sometimes mimicking breast cancer, especially inflammatory breast cancer, which necessitates evaluation with imaging with ultrasound and core needle biopsy to distinguish between the two. Biopsy will show non-necrotizing granulomatous lesions. Treatment typically involves watchful waiting as it can self-resolve,  antibiotics if superinfection occurs, and occasionally, corticosteroids  

Option Analysis

✅ Granulomatous mastitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Galactocele:
Incorrect: A galactocele (milk retention cyst) is a benign cyst in the breast caused by an obstructed milk duct. Galactoceles occur almost exclusively in lactating women. Patients with galactoceles present with non-tender soft cystic masses without associated systemic signs and symptoms.
❌ Fat necrosis of the breast:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis typically presents as a painless mass in the breast, often following trauma or surgery. It would not cause recurrent, painful episodes with purulent discharge and a sinus tract. These findings are typical of granulomatous mastitis.
❌ Acute non-puerperal mastitis:
Incorrect: Acute non-puerperal mastitis usually arises from a bacterial infection, presenting with localized pain, redness, and swelling. However, the recurrent nature of this patient's episodes, especially with incomplete resolution on antibiotics, is more suggestive of a chronic granulomatous process.
❌ Mammary ductal ectasia:
Incorrect: Mammary ductal ectasia typically occurs in perimenopausal women and presents with nipple discharge of various colors including green or black, sometimes with a palpable mass. The recurrent, painful episodes with sinus tract formation experienced by this patient are consistent with granulomatous mastitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic after noticing a breast mass on self-breast examination. The patient is a Navy Seal officer and recently returned from a 1-week rescue operation. Her last mammogram was 4 months ago and was normal. Past medical history is significant for hypertension treated with amlodipine/valsartan. Upon return from active duty, the military clinic recommended regular doses of acetaminophen to treat her pain from muscle contusions. The patient’s family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s aunt, diagnosed at the age of 76. The patient has regular menstruation. Temperature is 36.9 °C (98.42 °F), heart rate is 60 bpm, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg. Breast examination reveals a mildly tender 1.5 cm irregular-shaped firm breast mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast that is fixed to the dermis. There is overlying greenish-brownish discoloration of the skin. There is no nipple discharge. The right breast shows no abnormality. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given the patient's recent normal mammography findings, history suggestive of trauma, and localized breast ecchymosis (greenish-brown discoloration); fat necrosis of the breast is the most likely diagnosis.    

Fat necrosis is a benign breast lesion that can develop after breast trauma. Trauma associated with fat necrosis may be related to direct, blunt trauma or surgical interventions such as injection of native or foreign substances such as silicone, breast reconstruction, and breast reduction surgery. Traumatic fat necrosis is generally associated with localized skin ecchymosis (greenish-brown discoloration).  

In most cases, fat necrosis can be diagnosed clinically or radiographically. However, in some cases differentiating between fat necrosis and malignant breast masses can be challenging, and core needle biopsy may be necessary to exclude breast cancer. Patients can be treated conservatively with ice or heat and pain medication if necessary. Excision is not necessary because there is no increased risk of subsequent breast cancer. 

Option Analysis

✅ Fat necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Invasive ductal carcinoma :
Incorrect: This patient’s history of trauma, breast ecchymosis (e.g., greenish-brownish discoloration) seen on exam, and recent negative mammography make invasive ductal carcinoma less likely. Fat necrosis of the breast can be difficult to distinguish from malignancy by clinical exam alone, and mammography and occasionally tissue diagnosis may be necessary.
❌ Fibroadenoma:
Incorrect: Fibroadenomas usually present as painless, solitary, rubbery, well-defined, mobile masses in women between the ages of 14-35 years. This patient has a tender firm fixed mass with overlying ecchymoses that is most consistent with fat necrosis.
❌ Galactocele:
Incorrect: Galactoceles are milk-retention cysts. They commonly occur during pregnancy, lactation, or after weaning. They typically present as soft cystic painless masses. This patient has a mildly tender firm fixed mass with overlying ecchymoses that is most consistent with fat necrosis.
❌ Solitary intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: Solitary intraductal papilloma presents with clear or bloody nipple discharge. Masses related to solitary intraductal papillomas are typically located in the central duct just behind the nipple, not in the upper outer quadrant; and overlying ecchymoses would not be present. This patient has a mildly tender firm fixed mass with overlying ecchymoses that is most consistent with fat necrosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents for follow-up of a core biopsy done for microcalcifications seen on screening mammography. Past medical history is significant for hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 36.9 °C (98.42°F), heart rate is 72 bpm, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 139/96 mmHg.  The biopsy report shows no evidence of invasive ductal or lobular carcinoma. However, lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is noted with small cell proliferation with distinctive cell borders and small, uniform round-to-oval nuclei. After a thorough risk assessment, the management plan calls for close follow-up with an increased frequency of breast exams and breast imaging. Based on the pathology findings and the management strategy, which of the following was most likely diagnosed?

choices.text: Solitary intraductal papilloma with atypical cells

questions.solution:
Pathology in classic LCIS shows small cell proliferation with distinctive cell borders and small, uniform round-to-oval nuclei. Although the acini are distended, the overall architecture of the lobule and its basement membrane remain intact. Classic LCIS cells are typically estrogen receptor-positive and have a very low proliferative rate. Management includes surveillance with clinical breast exams every 6-12 months and yearly breast imaging with mammography and possibly breast MRI.   

Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is considered a high-risk breast lesion because it is associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer in the future in either breast. There are different types of LCIS and the classic type is not considered a malignant lesion. It is most often discovered incidentally when core needle biopsy is done for a different reason. Incidentally discovered classic LCIS where there is radiologic-pathologic concordance and no other high-risk lesions requiring excision, can be observed with clinical and imaging follow-up.   

Chemoprevention with a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) like tamoxifen should be considered for all patients with LCIS because it can significantly reduce the risk of future breast cancer. Patients with LCIS should be counseled about risk reduction strategies for modifiable lifestyle factors, such as regular exercise, maintenance of a normal BMI, and limited alcohol use. High-risk patients including those with known BRCA mutations, significant family histories of breast or ovarian cancer, or prior thoracic radiation at any age up to thirty years should be referred to a breast surgeon to discuss prophylactic surgery.

Option Analysis

✅ Classic LCIS:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pleomorphic LCIS:
Incorrect: Pleomorphic LCIS is made up of larger cells that demonstrate marked nuclear pleomorphism, but otherwise demonstrate the same characteristics as classic LCIS. Pleomorphic LCIS also often demonstrates central necrosis and calcifications. Pleomorphic LCIS is a more aggressive lesion than the classic LCIS and surgical excision with clean margins is recommended.
❌ Florid LCIS:
Incorrect: Florid LCIS is characterized by marked distension of the involved ducts and lobules, and mass formation. Often there is central necrosis, which may calcify. Florid type LCIS is considered a more aggressive lesion than classic LCIS and surgical excision with clean margins is recommended.
❌ Atypical ductal hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) is characterized by a proliferation of uniform epithelial cells with monomorphic round nuclei either filling part of the involved duct or completely filling the duct but measuring <2 mm or involving <2 ducts. The standard of care is excisional breast biopsy to exclude associated malignant lesions.
❌ Solitary intraductal papilloma with atypical cells:
Incorrect: Solitary intraductal papilloma with atypical cells is composed of papillary cells that grow from the wall of a cyst into its lumen. Solitary intraductal papillomas with atypical cells require surgical excision.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of breast pain. She is six weeks postpartum and has been breastfeeding her newborn without any issues until three days ago when she started experiencing left breast pain, scant thick yellow nipple discharge, and malaise. She is not taking any medications. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a tender, warm and erythematous area in the lower outer quadrant of the left breast. No masses are palpated and there is no axillary lymphadenopathy. There is scant thick yellow discharge and crusting at the nipple. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with acute onset unilateral breast pain, purulent nipple discharge and malaise, along with fever of 100.4°F and physical examination findings of breast erythema, warmth, and tenderness most likely has acute mastitis. Breastfeeding is a risk factor for mastitis as it leads to the formation of small cracks on the nipple through which bacteria can penetrate the tissue.  

History and physical examination play an important role in the diagnosis of nipple discharge. It is important to know whether the onset is acute or chronic, and if the discharge is unilateral (local pathology) or bilateral (hormonal). It is also important to know the color and appearance of discharge and any associated findings (fever, malaise, signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism, etc.). Manual pressure can be applied around the areola in an effort to elicit discharge. On physical examination, it is important to assess for lumps, asymmetries, and changes to the breast skin, nipple, and areola; and to assess for regional lymphadenopathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a benign epithelial tumor that typically presents with non-painful unilateral bloody nipple discharge. Erythema, pain and tenderness, and fever are not usually present; and in this patient likely indicate acute bacterial mastitis.
❌ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive ductal carcinoma typically presents as a firm, immobile, painless lump in the breast. Though it can occasionally be associated with nipple discharge, the discharge is usually not purulent. This patient’s acute presentation with fever, erythema, pain, and purulent discharge makes mastitis more likely. 
✅ Acute bacterial mastitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mammary duct ectasia:
Incorrect: Mammary duct ectasia is a benign disease in which a duct of a breast lobule thickens, causing blockage and buildup of fluid inside the lobule. It can present with off-white or greenish nipple discharge. It can result in findings similar to mastitis. However, this patient with acute onset breast pain and fever in the setting of breastfeeding most likely has isolated acute bacterial mastitis.
❌ Paget disease of the breast:
Incorrect: Paget disease of the breast typically presents as a scaly, ulcerated or vesicular appearing lesion that forms around the nipple and may extend to the surrounding areola. It can be accompanied by bloody discharge from the nipple. Frequently, patients experience pain, a burning sensation, and pruritus is a common initial symptom. This patient’s acute breast pain and tenderness, purulent discharge and erythema on exam is likely secondary to acute mastitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for a month-long history of bilateral milky nipple discharge. Review of systems is significant for 2 months of constipation and weight gain of 3.0 kg (6.6 lbs). Her menstrual cycles have become irregular recently. Her most recent menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She completed breastfeeding her infant 6 months ago and is currently not taking any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 28. On physical examination, a small amount of bilateral milky discharge is expressed with palpation of  the areola. Visual fields are intact. Deep tendon reflexes are delayed. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Human chorionic gonadotropin testing is negative. Serum prolactin level is 78 ng/mL (78 μg/L). A brain MRI is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation?

choices.text: Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 measurement

questions.solution:
This patient with bilateral milky discharge likely has physiologic galactorrhea. Associated findings of constipation, weight gain, bradycardia and delayed reflexes along with increased prolactin level and a negative MRI makes primary hypothyroidism-associated hyperprolactinemia most likely, and the patient should be evaluated further with TSH and free T4 measurements.    

Galactorrhea can be physiologic or pathologic. Physiologic galactorrhea is usually bilateral, multiductal nipple discharge that is white, clear, or milky. Though considered normal in peripartum and lactating women, it should further be evaluated if an alternative etiology is suspected or if patients are not pregnant or lactating. For instance, in patients with primary hypothyroidism, the hypothalamus attempts to boost the production of thyroid hormones by releasing more thyrotropin releasing hormone which also stimulates prolactin release, causing galactorrhea. Another cause of physiologic galactorrhea includes medications such as dopamine antagonists, that oppose the action of dopamine and removes the inhibition on the lactotroph cells, leading to hyperprolactinemia. Other causes of physiologic galactorrhea include prolactinoma from pituitary adenoma and chronic kidney disease.  



Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 measurement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cabergoline therapy:
Incorrect: Cabergoline therapy can be considered in patients with prolactinomas from pituitary adenomas to lower prolactin levels, reduce tumor size, and restore gonadal function. This patient with signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism and a negative MRI likely has galactorrhea secondary to primary hyperthyroidism and increased thyrotropin releasing hormone which stimulates prolactin release, causing galactorrhea.  
❌ Combined oral contraceptive therapy:
Incorrect: Combined oral contraceptive therapy can be used to treat irregular menses. However, this patient most likely has irregular menses and galactorrhea secondary to hypothyroidism, which should be diagnosed and treated first.
❌ Head CT:
Incorrect: Brain MRI not head CT should be performed in the evaluation of patients with physiologic nipple discharge to rule out a prolactinoma as the cause.
❌ Breast ultrasound:
Incorrect: Breast ultrasound is usually performed for evaluation of breast lumps or pathologic discharge. Pathologic discharge is usually unilateral, uniductal discharge that is bloody, serous or purulent. This patient’s bilateral, milky discharge with hyperprolactinemia and signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism and a negative MRI indicates physiologic discharge from primary hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for three weeks of discharge from the nipple of the left breast. The discharge is mostly clear, but it sometimes appears red. There is no associated breast pain, breast lump, fever, or weight loss. The patient’s last screening mammogram was ten months ago and was normal. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/83 mmHg. Chaperoned exam of the left breast reveals a smooth contour to the skin without erythema or warmth. No masses are palpated. Serosanguineous fluid can be manually expressed from the nipple. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with unilateral serosanguineous nipple discharge and should have initial imaging with a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound.    

Patients with breast papillomas may present with clear or bloody nipple drainage, a palpable mass, or with abnormal findings detected on breast imaging. The initial step in the workup of a suspected breast papilloma is diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound. Additional testing is indicated if ultrasound and mammogram are negative or do not show an area suitable for biopsy. Additional imaging may include ductoscopy, galactography, or breast MRI. A tissue sample, usually collected by core needle biopsy, is needed to make the diagnosis of a papilloma and assess for atypical or malignant cells as imaging alone cannot make this distinction.  

The classic histological findings of a breast papilloma are intraductal fibrovascular stalks lined by orderly layers of myoepithelial cells and ductal epithelial cells. Focal necrosis may or may not be present. A breast papilloma may be a benign lesion, or atypical or malignant cells may be contained within the mass. Low-grade proliferation of atypical epithelial cells within a papilloma is characterized as either atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) if the proliferation is less than 3 mm in size without malignant features, or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) when the proliferation is ≥ 3 mm. When intermediate or high-grade atypia is present within a papilloma, it is characterized as DCIS regardless of size. Malignant cells within a papilloma may extend into the adjacent breast tissue and cause localized or invasive carcinoma. Distinguishing between benign papilloma, papilloma with atypia, and papilloma with neoplasm will guide management and determine the need for preoperative staging, surgical treatment plan, and the post-surgical treatment plan.

Option Analysis

✅ Diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ductoscopy:
Incorrect: Ductoscopy is a technique where a small scope is inserted directly into the duct through its opening at the nipple and provides both a visual examination of the inside of the duct and the ability to collect a tissue biopsy. Ductoscopy is an option in the workup of a papilloma if mammography and ultrasound do not show a mass or other suspicious area to biopsy.
❌ Galactography:
Incorrect: Galactography is an option in the workup of a breast papilloma if mammography and ultrasound do not identify a mass or other suspicious area to biopsy. Contrast dye is injected into the affected duct followed by mammography images to outline the shape of the duct and evaluate for a filling defect.
❌ Breast MR:
Incorrect: MRI has a high sensitivity for detecting lesions in the breast. However, there is significant overlap in the appearance of benign and malignant lesions on MRI, often creating the need for additional workup, cost, and patient stress. MRI is typically done when other imaging modalities have failed to detect a lesion.
❌ Core needle biopsy:
Incorrect: Core needle biopsy is done when a mass or other suspicious finding is detected on imaging in a suspected breast papilloma. Imaging is needed to guide the location for the biopsy; therefore, an initial diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound should be performed first.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for evaluation of a tender right breast lump. She noticed the lump three weeks ago right before menstruation, and it has not changed in size since that time. She does not have nipple discharge. She does not take any daily medications. She has regular menses and uses condoms for birth control. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. The skin of the right breast is normal, and there is no nipple discharge. Breast examination reveals a 1-cm smooth, mobile, mildly tender mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There is no  bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat breast exam two weeks after the start of her menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
This premenopausal patient has a solitary, smooth, tender, mobile right breast mass, which is characteristic of a breast cyst. Breast ultrasound is the next step to confirm the diagnosis and to determine if aspiration or core needle biopsy is necessary.

Breast cysts are fluid filled masses that develop within the glandular tissue of the breast, usually in the upper outer quadrant, but they can appear anywhere in the breast. Breast cysts usually develop because of overproduction of estrogen and suppression of progesterone. Patients with breast cysts may present with a breast mass and localized pain that worsens prior to menstruation, or patients may be asymptomatic with a breast lump found on a routine self examination or physical examination in a provider’s office. Breast cysts are typically solitary, smooth, firm lesions that are mobile and may or may not be tender to palpation. Most breast cysts are benign, but new cysts in older postmenopausal patients pose a higher risk of malignancy.

Option Analysis

✅ Breast ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Estrogen, LH, and FSH levels:
Incorrect: Although breast cysts usually develop because of overproduction of estrogen and suppression of progesterone, obtaining hormone levels is not part of the diagnosis or treatment. This patient has symptoms and findings consistent with a breast cyst, and she should have a breast ultrasound to diagnose and classify her lesion.  
❌ Repeat breast exam two weeks after the start of her menstrual cycle:
Incorrect: Fibrocystic breast disease commonly presents with bilateral nodularity and breast tenderness that can worsen towards the end of a patient’s menstrual cycle. In addition to bilateral tender nodular areas in the breasts, a ropey or lumpy texture may be palpable. This premenopausal patient has a smooth, mobile, tender mass that is consistent with a breast cyst. She should have an ultrasound for diagnosis and classification.  
❌ Skin biopsy:
Incorrect: A skin biopsy is usually performed when a patient has symptoms suspicious for inflammatory breast cancer, such as pruritus, warmth, and erythema of the skin of the breast; nipple flattening or retractions; and axillary lymphadenopathy. None of these are present in this patient.  
❌ Percutaneous aspiration of the mass:
Incorrect: A breast abscess or cyst may be aspirated percutaneously, which is usually done after or during a breast ultrasound. A breast ultrasound is first needed to diagnose the lesion which will, in turn, determine next steps in management.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for evaluation of a tender left breast lump. She found the lump during a self-breast examination three weeks ago, and it has not changed in size during that time. She does not have nipple discharge. She has no significant past medical history. She has had irregular menses for the past year. She is not sexually active. Her paternal aunt had breast cancer when she was in her 80’s. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. The skin of the breast is normal, and there is no nipple discharge. Breast examination reveals a 1.5-cm smooth, mobile mass in the upper outer right breast that is very tender upon palpation. There is no bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. Breast ultrasound reveals an irregular shaped lesion with walls that are 0.40 mm thick with posterior acoustic enhancement and no solid components. Which of the following features supports ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy as the best next diagnostic step?

choices.text: Irregular shape of the breast lump on ultrasound
Absence of solid components on ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient has a solitary, tender, mobile left breast mass that is suspicious for a breast cyst.  On breast ultrasound, the patient has a mass with irregular borders. The cyst is classified as a complex breast cyst that is considered suspicious for malignancy (BI-RAD classification 4 or 5, suspicious for malignancy or highly suggestive of malignancy). Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy should be performed next to provide histopathology to further assess the mass.

Breast ultrasound is the initial test to evaluate breast masses that are suspected to be cysts and to confirm the diagnosis of a breast cyst. Breast ultrasound can also differentiate between simple, complicated, and complex breast cysts. This determination will then guide management. Ultrasound classification of breast cysts is based on lesion shape, acoustic enhancement, internal echoes, solid components, and the thickness of the walls and septa of the mass.  

Option Analysis

✅ Irregular shape of the breast lump on ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Family history of breast cancer:
Incorrect: Regardless of this patient’s family history, findings from the ultrasound, including an irregular shaped lesion, should be used to guide diagnosis and management. This patient with an irregular shaped lesion should have an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy.  
❌ Absence of solid components on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Absence of solid components in a breast cyst can be found in simple, complicated, and complex breast cysts and does not differentiate between the types of breast cysts. This patient with an irregular shaped lesion should have an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy.  
❌ Age of the patient:
Incorrect: Regardless of the patient’s age, a breast mass that is found to have features that are suspicious for malignancy, like lobulated, indistinct or irregular borders, solid components, or thick walls, should have an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy.  
❌ Presence of pain with palpation:
Incorrect: Benign and malignant breast masses may be tender or painful; therefore, tenderness or pain alone does not determine the underlying cause of a cyst. Cysts that may be malignant should be biopsied with ultrasound guidance.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist's office for a routine gynecologic examination. She has no complaints. She has no known medical conditions. She uses a copper IUD for birth control. She has no family history of cancer. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. The skin of the breast is normal and there is no nipple discharge. Breast examination reveals a 1-cm smooth, nontender, mobile mass in the upper outer left breast. There is no bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. Breast ultrasound reveals an oval-shaped lesion with posterior acoustic enhancement and walls that are 0.40 mm thick. There are internal echoes but no solid components. Her mammogram is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Clinical breast exam and breast ultrasound in six months

questions.solution:
This patient has a solitary, nontender, mobile left breast mass found on routine breast examination. Her breast ultrasound confirms that the mass is a complicated breast cyst (Bi-rads 2 or 3). Patients with complicated breast cysts should undergo a clinical breast examination, repeat breast ultrasound, and mammogram if the lesion was initially seen on mammography in six months.

Management of patients with  breast cysts is based on the type of cyst diagnosed on ultrasound. Patients with simple cysts may undergo ultrasound-guided aspiration if the patient is symptomatic. Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is recommended for simple cysts if the cyst does not completely collapse after aspiration or if there is bloody aspirate. Patients with complicated cysts (Bi-rads 3) should have follow-up, including clinical breast examination and breast ultrasound in six months as well as mammogram if the lesion was seen initially on mammogram. Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is recommended if the cyst increases in size on follow-up imaging or if solid components are found on follow-up imaging. Patients with complex cyst with solid components should undergo ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy due to the high risk of malignancy. If the biopsy results show atypical or malignant cells, excisional biopsy should be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Clinical breast exam and breast ultrasound in six months:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound-guided aspiration:
Incorrect: Ultrasound-guided aspiration may be used to treat patients with symptomatic simple cysts diagnosed on ultrasound. They are not used to diagnose or manage patients with complicated cysts.  
❌ Excisional biopsy:
Incorrect: Excisional biopsy is not necessary at this time since the ultrasound shows a complicated cyst that can be reassessed in six months.  
❌ Mammogram in six months:
Incorrect: Follow up for a complicated cyst includes clinical breast exam and ultrasound in six months. Mammogram can also be performed if the lesion was initially seen on mammogram. This patient’s initial mammogram was negative, so follow-up with clinical breast exam and ultrasound in six months is appropriate.  
❌ Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy:
Incorrect: Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is performed in patients with breast cysts when their ultrasound and/or mammographic assessments indicate lesions that are suspicious for malignancy. When findings show a complicated cyst, assessments can be repeated in six months.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is 7 weeks postpartum presents to her primary care physician with a 3-day history of increasing pain, redness, and swelling in her right breast. She has been exclusively breastfeeding her infant and recently noted a decrease in milk output from the affected breast. She has not had trauma or recent surgeries. Past medical history is notable for gestational diabetes, which was managed with diet during her pregnancy. She has no known bacterial colonization. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination of the right breast reveals erythema, warmth, and tenderness to palpation noted in the upper outer quadrant. There is no fluctuance. The left breast is normal on examination. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Dicloxacillin and frequent breastfeeding or pumping
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and frequent breastfeeding or pumping
Intravenous vancomycin and ultrasound-guided needle aspiration
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and frequent breastfeeding or pumping

questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of localized pain and erythema of the breast, coupled with fever and postpartum status, strongly suggests puerperal mastitis. Puerperal mastitis commonly occurs in breastfeeding women, typically within the first 6 weeks postpartum. Management consists of antibiotic therapy and continuation of breastfeeding or pumping.    

Antibiotic treatment should target common pathogens like Staphylococcus aureus. Dicloxacillin is the preferred antibiotic due to its efficacy against penicillinase-producing staphylococci and its safety with breastfeeding. In addition to antibiotic therapy, continued breastfeeding or pumping from the affected breast should be encouraged in order to prevent milk stasis which could worsen the infection. Additionally, pain control with NSAIDs is recommended to alleviate inflammation and discomfort. If there is no improvement with initial treatment, or if an abscess is suspected, a breast ultrasound should be considered for further evaluation. Detection of an abscess necessitates drainage, which may be done surgically or with ultrasound guidance. In such cases, antibiotic therapy may need adjustment to cover potential methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

Option Analysis

✅ Dicloxacillin and frequent breastfeeding or pumping:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cephalexin and discontinuation of breastfeeding :
Incorrect: Dicloxacillin or cephalexin are appropriate antibiotics to treat mild mastitis infection when there are no MRSA risk factors, however, continued milk drainage is recommended to prevent milk stasis.
❌ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and frequent breastfeeding or pumping:
Incorrect: Although NSAIDs can help with pain and inflammation with mastitis, this patient has fever and chills suggestive of a bacterial infection and needs antibiotic therapy.
❌ Intravenous vancomycin and ultrasound-guided needle aspiration:
Incorrect: This approach is too aggressive for initial management of mastitis in a lactating woman without confirmation of abscess or risk for resistant bacteria.
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and frequent breastfeeding or pumping:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is appropriate treatment for puerperal mastitis in patients with risk factors for MRSA like recent hospitalization or colonization with MRSA which are not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a rash on her left breast. The patient first noticed a scaly, itchy rash that began on her left nipple two weeks ago and now has spread to the lateral aspect of the breast. Before the appearance of the rash, she experienced some burning pain on the left nipple. There is no significant family medical history. Vital signs are unremarkable. Physical exam is notable for an eczematous lesion involving the left nipple with several excoriations extending laterally. No nipple discharge is noted, and the lymph node basins are unremarkable. A full-thickness punch biopsy is taken, and several days later it shows malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) occurring singly or in small groups within the epidermis of the nipple. A diagnostic mammography shows a 3 cm lesion in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast, and a biopsy of the lesion shows ER+/PR+/HER2- invasive ductal carcinoma. Which of the following is the correct stage of this patient’s breast cancer?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an eczematous lesion involving her left nipple and lateral breast associated with pain and itching. Biopsy reveals Paget cells, and diagnostic mammography with biopsy diagnoses the patient with hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative, invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3 cm. Given that the lymph node exam is negative, this makes her T2cN0MX or Stage IIA.  

Patients with Paget disease of the breast typically present with a scaly, vesicular, or ulcerated lesion that begins on the nipple and spreads to the areola. Bloody nipple discharge may be seen. Pain, burning, and pruritus are commonly associated and often experienced before the lesion appears. It is typically associated with an underlying breast cancer in that breast.  

Patients with Paget disease of the breast have underlying breast cancer (in situ or invasive) in 85 to 88 percent of cases, although often without an associated palpable breast mass or screening mammographic abnormality. Therefore, all patients require a full-thickness skin biopsy and diagnostic mammography. Staging for breast cancer involves the TNM system: tumor, node, and metastasis. Early-stage breast cancer includes patients with stage I, IIA, and a subset of stage IIB, while locally advanced breast cancer includes patients with a subset of stage IIB, IIIA to IIIC.  

Most patients with early-stage disease can be offered surgery +/- chemotherapy/hormone therapy depending on the receptor status. Whereas, for locally advanced breast cancer, neoadjuvant chemotherapy is usually recommended before surgery. Metastatic workup is only completed in locally advanced (disease that is T3 or greater, N2 or N3, M0), cases of inflammatory breast cancer, and in any patients with signs or symptoms suspicious of metastatic disease. 

Option Analysis

❌ Stage IA:
Incorrect: Stage IA patients are T1 (< 2cm) and cN0 (no palpable nodes). This patient’s lesion is larger than 2cm. Therefore she is stage IIA.
❌ Stage IIB:
Incorrect: Stage IIB is T2N1 or T3N0 disease; N1 disease means metastasis to ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes. This patient has T2N0 disease without lymph node spread and therefore is stage IIA. 
✅ Stage IIA:
Correct: See main explanation.
❌ Stage IIIA:
Incorrect: This involves T0-3 with N2 disease or T3N1 disease. T3 is > 5 cm. This patient’s lesion is 3 cm. 
❌ Stage IV:
Incorrect: Stage IV disease is any metastatic disease and/or inflammatory breast cancer, which involves the overlying skin.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for routine breast cancer screening. She has no breast symptoms, and there is no significant personal or family history of breast or ovarian cancer. The patient does not take any medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. A clinical breast exam is unremarkable aside from dense breast tissue, and the screening mammogram is categorized as BI-RADS 0. Which of the following best describes the screening results and subsequent recommendations?

choices.text: No abnormalities detected; continue with routine screening
Benign findings; continue with routine screening
Highly suggestive of malignancy; obtain a tissue biopsy
Breasts are extremely dense; 3D mammography is recommended
The study is incomplete; further imaging is needed

questions.solution:
This healthy biologically female patient with average risk for breast cancer receives a screening mammogram categorized as BI-RADS 0. The BI-RADS 0 category indicates that the initial screening mammogram is incomplete, often due to factors such as dense breast tissue, technical issues, or the need for additional views. This classification signals that further imaging, such as diagnostic mammography, ultrasound, or MRI, is necessary to assess whether any abnormalities are present.

For women at average or moderate risk, routine mammography screening typically begins at age 40 and continues annually or biennially, depending on individual preference and local guidelines. Screening usually continues until age 75, or until life expectancy is less than 10 years.

The BI-RADS system standardizes the interpretation and reporting of breast imaging, with each category guiding subsequent management, which is outlined in the table above. Management may include continuing routine screening; clinical breast exam and short-term follow-up; or image-guided core needle or excisional biopsy for tissue diagnosis. BI-RADS 6 indicates a biopsy-confirmed malignant lesion that requires a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation.

Option Analysis

❌ No abnormalities detected; continue with routine screening:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the interpretation of BI-RADS 1. BI-RADS 0 is an incomplete study, and further imaging is needed.
❌ Benign findings; continue with routine screening:
Incorrect: Benign findings are categorized as BI-RADS 2. BI-RADS 0 indicates that the study is incomplete, and additional imaging is required.
❌ Highly suggestive of malignancy; obtain a tissue biopsy:
Incorrect: Lesions highly suggestive of malignancy are categorized as BI-RADS 5 and require a tissue biopsy. BI-RADS 0 indicates an incomplete study, and further imaging is needed.
❌ Breasts are extremely dense; 3D mammography is recommended:
Incorrect: While dense breast tissue may complicate imaging and contribute to a BI-RADS 0 result, BI-RADS 0 specifically refers to an incomplete study, not just the density of the breasts. Further imaging techniques, such as additional mammography views, ultrasound, or MRI, may be necessary.
✅ The study is incomplete; further imaging is needed:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female collegiate pole vaulter presents to the OB/GYN clinic for evaluation of right-sided breast discomfort that has persisted for three weeks. The pain is described as dull and aching, rated 4 on a 10-point scale, and worsens with upper body activity but is otherwise constant. On review of systems, there is increased muscle soreness in the patient’s neck and shoulder. Medical history is unremarkable, with no medications and no family history of breast cancer. There has been no recent trauma or surgery. Pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. The patient appears clinically well and in no significant distress. Which of the following additional physical exam findings would best support the likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patients with a history of repetitive upper body movements who present with breast pain that worsens with physical activity, particularly when accompanied by neck, shoulder, or upper back discomfort, are most likely to have extramammary chest wall pain. Pain that is reproduced by palpation or upper body movement strongly suggests a musculoskeletal source rather than a breast-related condition such as mastitis or a tumor.   

Evaluation of mastalgia requires a focused history and thorough physical examination to distinguish benign causes from those requiring further investigation, including assessment of pain characteristics, duration, and triggers as well as identification of any physical findings such as tenderness, masses, or skin changes.   



Option Analysis

❌ Fever :
Incorrect: Fever suggests an infectious or inflammatory process such as lactational mastitis, which typically presents with focal erythema, warmth, and systemic symptoms. This patient is not lactating and appears well. 
❌ Palpable mass:
Incorrect: The patient’s young age makes malignancy less likely. A simple breast cyst is possible, but the vignette most strongly supports chest wall pain given the history of repetitive upper body activity as a pole vaulter and concurrent neck and shoulder soreness. 
❌ Nipple discharge:
Incorrect: Discharge is more often associated with intraductal lesions, endocrine disorders, duct ectasia, or malignancy. However, given the history of repetitive upper body activity as a pole vaulter and concurrent neck and shoulder soreness, musculoskeletal chest wall pain is the most likely diagnosis in this case, which is not associated with nipple discharge. 
❌ Normal exam:
Incorrect: A normal breast exam can occur with cyclic or noncyclic mastalgia. While non-cyclic mastalgia is possible, this patient’s history of repetitive upper body movement and concurrent neck and shoulder pain suggest chest wall pain, which would be confirmed by reproducing the pain on exam. 
✅ Reproducible pain on palpation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office to establish routine healthcare. He recently moved to California to live with his daughter after the death of his spouse. The patient has no active complaints. Past medical history is significant for hemorrhoids. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus in his father and prostate cancer in his paternal grandfather. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years; he does not drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination shows irregular nodularity on the posterior prostate. The rest of the examination is normal. Serum prostate specific antigen is 7 ng/mL. Medical recods show that it was 4.5 ng/mL a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings of a family history of prostate cancer, an elevated prostate specific antigen (PSA) and irregular nodularity on digital rectal examination (DRE) raises concern for a possible development of prostate adenocarcinoma.   

Since this patient has a life expectancy of more than 10 years, these findings warrant further evaluation with ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy. Biopsy findings of glandular crowding (lacking branching and papillary infoldings) with nuclear atypia (enlarged nuclei, prominent nucleoli and dark cytoplasm) is suggestive of the diagnosis.  


Histological specimen showing acinar type adenocarcinoma obtained by core needle prostate biopsy
Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

In addition to PSA levels, grading and staging of prostate adenocarcinoma are excellent prognostic predictors. Gleason score is used for grading and is based on glandular patterns of differentiation, with grade 1 being well-differentiated representing most favorable prognosis and grade 5 with no glandular differentiation representing poor prognosis. Staging is done using the TNM system, which is based on information from biopsy, DRE and imaging studies.  



Option Analysis

❌ Expressed prostatic secretions culture:
Incorrect: Expressed prostatic secretions culture is usually performed in suspected prostatitis and to differentiate between bacterial and abacterial prostatitis. This DRE is indicative of a malignancy.
✅ Ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ MRI spine:
Incorrect: This patient with irregular nodularity on DRE and an elevated serum PSA should initially undergo biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. MRI spine can be performed at a later stage based on biopsy findings to further assess the tumor burden and guide management plan.
❌ Obtain prostatic acid phosphatase levels:
Incorrect: Prostatic acid phosphatase is an enzyme found in the prostate and can sometimes be elevated in prostate cancer. However, it is nonspecific and is rarely used after the advent of PSA.
❌ Urinalysis:
Incorrect: Urinalysis is not indicated in an asymptomatic patient with normal vitals and DRE suggestive of a malignancy. Prostate biopsy is more appropriate at this time.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to his primary care doctor’s office after he felt a right testicular mass a week ago. He notes he has had a dull, intermittent ache in his groin for the past 2 months, which has had attributed to strenuous exercises as a personal trainer. His past medical history is significant for surgical correction of right-sided cryptorchidism at the age of 1. On physical examination, the patient’s right testicle is non-tender, but a firm and fixed mass is palpated. Transillumination is negative. An ultrasound of the right testicle demonstrates a heterogenous mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Core needle biopsy of the mass
Fine needle aspiration of the mass

questions.solution:
This male patient presents with a history of dull, achy groin pain and a nontender testicular mass, which raises concerns for a testicular tumor. The transillumination test, which is performed by shining a light behind the scrotum, confirms the mass being solid, as light is blocked by the mass. If a firm mass is identified, a scrotal ultrasound should be performed, as ultrasound is the first-line imaging in patients who present with a testicular abnormality. The findings of a heterogeneous mass on ultrasound further confirm the presence of a testicular tumor.

When testicular tumors are highly suspected, the testicular mass is not biopsied, since lymph from the scrotum is drained by the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, and thus a biopsy would lead to an open route for lymphatic metastasis. The best next step after performing an ultrasound is to draw serum tumor markers. The initial evaluation should include measurement of beta-hCG, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), as elevations of specific markers can help diagnose the type of testicular cancer. It is important to note that serum tumor markers should be drawn before surgery; tumor markers can be used in tracking remission and relapse of the cancer, and if the tumor markers are drawn after surgery, they may be falsely low. Additionally, after orchiectomy has been performed, a follow up CT abdomen and pelvis for staging should be ordered.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Core needle biopsy of the mass:
Incorrect: Testicular tumors should not be biopsied, as lymph from the scrotum is drained by the superficial inguinal lymph nodes and not by the retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Cutting or obtaining a biopsy of the site leads to an open route for lymphatic metastasis. After orchiectomy has been performed, a follow up CT abdomen and pelvis for staging should be ordered.
❌ Positron emission tomography (PET) scan:
Incorrect: A PET scan is not commonly used in the initial diagnostic evaluation of a patient with a likely testicular tumor; instead, it is used for the evaluation of posttherapy residual masses.
✅ Obtain serum markers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fine needle aspiration of the mass:
Incorrect: Testicular tumors should not be biopsied, as lymph from the scrotum is drained by the superficial inguinal lymph nodes and not by the retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Cutting or obtaining a biopsy of the site leads to an open route for lymphatic metastasis.
❌ Radical orchiectomy:
Incorrect: Serum tumor markers should always be drawn before surgery. The tumor markers can be used in tracking remission and relapse of the cancer. If the tumor markers are drawn after surgery, they may be falsely low.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of left testicular mass. He first noticed the mass 3 weeks ago when he was taking a shower. It is painless and hard in consistency. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for lung cancer in the patient’s father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows firm ovoid left testes with a rubbery enlargement. The right testicle appears normal. Ultrasound of the testes shows a solid left testicular mass. A left orchiectomy is performed. A postoperative histologic and molecular analysis of the testes shows that the cancer cells are sensitive to etoposide. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient with a testicular mass is found to have testicular cancer. The cancer cells are sensitive to etoposide, which is a topoisomerase II inhibitor.       

Topoisomerases are enzymes that relieve the DNA supercoiling that occurs during DNA replication as a result of separation and unwinding of the DNA. Topoisomerase II makes double-stranded nicks to relieve negative supercoiling. Topoisomerase II inhibitors (e.g., etoposide and teniposide) bind to topoisomerase II and DNA to prevent the resealing of the break. The enzyme remains bound to the free end of the broken DNA strand, leading to an accumulation of DNA breaks and cell death. Cells in the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle are the most sensitive.        

Topoisomerase II inhibitors are indicated in the management of solid tumors (e.g., testicular and small cell lung cancer), leukemia, and lymphomas. Elimination is mainly through the kidneys, requiring dosage reduction in patients with renal dysfunction. Common adverse effects include myelosuppression, gastrointestinal disturbances, and alopecia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cross-links DNA  :
Incorrect: Platinum agent (e.g. cisplatin) cross-links DNA and is used in the pharmacologic management of testicular cancer. Etoposide does not belong to this class of anticancer drugs. 
❌ Inhibits thymidylate synthase :
Incorrect: 5-fluorouracil inhibits thymidylate synthase to halt DNA synthesis. It is used in the treatment of colon cancer, pancreatic cancer, and actinic keratosis, but not testicular cancer. 
❌ Intercalates into the DNA  :
Incorrect: Dactinomycin intercalates DNA and prevents the synthesis of RNA in the cancer cell. It is usually indicated in the management of childhood tumors (e.g., Wilms tumor, Ewing sarcoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma). 
✅ Inhibits topoisomerase II :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inhibits microtubule formation :
Incorrect: Microtubule inhibitors vinca alkaloids (e.g., vincristine and vinblastine) bind β-tubulin and inhibit its polymerization into microtubules. They are indicated in the treatment of solid tumors, leukemias, Hodgkin, and non-Hodgkin lymphomas. Etoposide does not belong to this class of anticancer drugs.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of painless right testicular swelling. The patient first noticed the swelling 3 months ago. He does not recall any injury to the scrotum. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a unilateral painless mass above the right hemiscrotum. An orchiectomy is performed, and the patient is diagnosed with stage three embryonal carcinoma of the testicle. He is started on chemotherapy. The patient’s grandfather passed away from pulmonary side effects associated with chemotherapy. As a result, the patient is hesitant to begin any drugs known to damage lung tissue. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with embryonal carcinoma of the testicle. Bleomycin can be used to treat the patient’s testicular cancer, as well as other conditions such as Hodgkin lymphoma and squamous cell carcinoma. The medication intercalates with DNA and generates free radicals in the presence of oxygen and iron, resulting in breaks in the DNA strand.

However, bleomycin is associated with severe pulmonary side effects. Lung tissue has low levels of the enzyme bleomycin hydrolase, which can inactivate the drug. As a result, the drug can cause interstitial pulmonary fibrosis, due to recurrent cycles of cell injury and repair, and pneumonitis. Pulmonary fibrosis can develop one to six months after initiating bleomycin treatment. It usually manifests as dyspnea, dry cough, and dry inspiratory crackles on physical examination.

Skin tissue also has low levels of bleomycin hydrolase. As a result, patients can also experience rash, exfoliation, and hyperpigmentation. In addition, the medication is associated with mucocutaneous side effects (e.g., mucositis, stomatitis) and alopecia.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Bleomycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cisplatin:
Incorrect: Cisplatin is a platinum-containing chemotherapeutic that crosslinks DNA. Side effects of cisplatin include nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. It does not typically cause pulmonary injury.  
❌ Vincristine:
Incorrect: Vincristine is a Vinca alkaloid that prevents the assembly of the B-tubulin into microtubules, thereby inhibiting mitotic spindle formation. Vincristine can cause peripheral neuropathy, constipation, and bone marrow suppression. However, it would not cause pulmonary toxicity.  
❌ Topotecan:
Incorrect: Topotecan causes DNA damage by inhibiting the enzyme topoisomerase I. Common toxicities of topotecan are myelosuppression and diarrhea. However, it is not known to cause pulmonary injury.  
❌ Teniposide:
Incorrect: Teniposide inhibits the enzyme topoisomerase II, thereby causing DNA breakages. Side effects include myelosuppression, alopecia, and gastrointestinal toxicity. It does not typically cause pulmonary injury.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for follow-up regarding a testicular mass. The patient noticed a small, painful lump on the right testicle one month ago. The patient’s father had testicular cancer at age 31. Three days ago, the patient underwent testicular ultrasound which showed a solid, right sided intratesticular mass. Serum studies, including complete blood count, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) are pending. A chest X-ray and computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal any additional lesions. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is a right-sided testicular mass that is tender to palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
