This 29-year-old man recently presented with a painful testicular lump, and ultrasonography revealed a solid intratesticular mass. Considering this patient’s family history, this presentation is very concerning for testicular cancer. The best next step is to proceed with unilateral orchiectomy.

Testicular cancer most commonly presents individuals with male reproductive anatomy aged 15-34 years, and treatment options depend on the type of testicular cancer. The most common types include seminoma, non-seminoma, mixed germ cell tumor, and sex cord/stromal tumors. The initial diagnostic workup generally includes scrotal ultrasound, serum tumor markers (e.g., hCG, LDH, AFP), and additional imaging (e.g., CT of the abdomen and pelvis, chest X-ray) to assess disease extent.

All patients with suspected testicular malignancy should undergo orchiectomy with pathologic analysis rather than biopsy due to the risk of hematogenous seeding. Patients should be counseled on the potential risks of infertility and hypogonadism, and sperm banking for future family planning should be discussed. Urology and oncology consultations will help guide subsequent treatment planning and recommendations, which may include retroperitoneal lymph node dissection, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and/or active surveillance, depending on the type and extent of disease.

Option Analysis

✅ Orchiectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection:
Incorrect: This option may be indicated depending upon the staging of the suspected testicular malignancy. However, final management cannot be determined until pathology results from the removed testicle are reviewed.
❌ Testicular biopsy:
Incorrect: When testicular cancer is suspected, orchiectomy should be performed instead of biopsy. Biopsy carries a theoretical risk of hematogenous seeding of the tumor.
❌ Localized radiation therapy:
Incorrect: Radiation may be indicated depending upon the type and stage of the suspected testicular malignancy. However, it cannot be initiated before pathology results from orchiectomy are available for staging and treatment planning.
❌ Intravenous chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Chemotherapy may be indicated depending on the type and stage of the suspected testicular malignancy. However, it cannot be initiated before pathology results from orchiectomy are available for staging and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic because of difficulty hearing. A month ago, he presented with a two-month history of pain in the groin. The pain was constant and had a "dragging" quality. Examination revealed an enlarged left testicle, and a firm, solid mass was noted on palpation. He subsequently underwent a left inguinal orchiectomy. Histopathology showed testicular cancer, and the patient was started on chemotherapy. Which of the following chemotherapeutic agents is most likely responsible for the patient’s current auditory symptoms?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is a platinum-containing chemotherapeutic agent. Other agents in this class include carboplatin and oxaliplatin. These agents inhibit DNA repair and replication by cross-linking adjacent guanines, preventing the DNA strands from being separated. Cisplatin has four main side effects:  

1. Ototoxicity: There are currently no effective treatment options. The extent of ototoxicity may be measured by audiometric analysis. Other drugs (e.g. aminoglycosides) may also cause ototoxicity, and the concurrent administration of this class of antibiotics in patients receiving cisplatin is generally avoided.  

2. Nephrotoxicity: Nephrotoxicity is the primary dose-limiting side effect. It is related to reactive oxygen species and, in animal models, can be ameliorated by free radical scavenging agents. The dose is decreased when the patient's creatinine clearance (a measure of renal function) is reduced. Adequate hydration and diuresis, in addition to amifostine (a free radical scavenger), are used to prevent this side effect.    

3. Nausea and vomiting: Cisplatin is highly emetogenic. This side effect can be treated with prophylactic antiemetics (e.g., ondansetron, granisetron) and corticosteroids.  

4. Neurotoxicity: This side effect usually presents as peripheral neuropathy.   

Option Analysis

❌ Bleomycin:
Incorrect: Bleomycin induces the formation of free radicals, which causes breaks in DNA strands. It is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis, skin changes, and occasionally bone marrow suppression.  
❌ Busulfan:
Incorrect: Busulfan is a DNA alkylator used to treat chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), other leukemias, lymphomas, and myeloproliferative disorders. It is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis and skin changes, including hyperpigmentation.  
✅ Cisplatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cytarabine:
Incorrect: Cytarabine is used mainly to treat cancers of white blood cells, such as acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It inhibits DNA polymerase and causes megaloblastic anemia and pancytopenia.  
❌ Doxorubicin:
Incorrect: Doxorubicin generates free radicals and intercalates into DNA, resulting in breaks in the DNA strand. It is used to treat leukemias, Hodgkin lymphoma, and solid tumors. Side effects include cardiotoxicity, hair loss, and bone marrow suppression.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the clinic with a six-month history of worsening urinary frequency, nocturia, difficulty initiating urination, and a weak urinary stream. He reports occasional dribbling at the end of urination. He has no hematuria, dysuria, unintentional weight loss, bone pain, or recent illnesses. Past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes, both well-controlled. He has no family history of prostate cancer. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft, non-distended, and non-tender. A digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals a nontender symmetrically enlarged prostate with a firm palpable nodule in the right lobe. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. Using the urinary symptom score/International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS), the patient has a 10. Laboratory tests show a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level of 10.2 ng/mL (normal <4 ng/mL). Urinalysis is negative for signs of infection and hematuria. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Start alpha-blocker and recheck PSA in six months
Repeat DRE and PSA in three months
Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the prostate

questions.solution:
This patient presents with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) consistent with benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) including urinary frequency, nocturia, difficulty initiating urination, and a weak urinary stream. A score of 10 on the urinary symptom score/International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) indicates moderate LUTS from BPH. However, in addition to this patient’s BPH symptoms, the findings of a palpable nodule on digital rectal examination (DRE) and markedly elevated PSA level are overly concerning for prostate cancer. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to perform a transrectal ultrasound (TRUS)-guided prostate biopsy, which will provide tissue for histopathologic evaluation to confirm or exclude malignancy. This is the gold standard for diagnosing prostate cancer when clinical suspicion is high.       

In patients diagnosed with BPH, a validated symptom questionnaire should be used to measure symptom severity, bother, and response to treatment at each visit. The International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) consists of seven questions related to voiding symptoms. Scores of 0 to 7, 8 to 19, and 20 to 35 signify mild, moderate, and severe symptoms, respectively.        

BPH is not associated with systemic symptoms and does not increase the risk of prostate cancer. In contrast, patients with prostate cancer may present with similar urinary symptoms but they often also have red-flag signs such as unintentional weight loss, bone pain, or hematuria if advanced. Some patients with prostate cancer may be asymptomatic but found to have persistently elevated or rapidly rising PSA levels concerning for malignancy. On DRE, prostate cancer may be suggested by an asymmetric gland, nodules, or induration. Patients with a family history of prostate cancer are at increased risk.   

Option Analysis

❌ Start alpha-blocker and recheck PSA in six months:
Incorrect: While alpha-blockers can improve lower urinary tract symptoms in patients with moderate benign prostatic hypertrophy (as seen in this patient with a score of 10), this approach fails to address the most concerning findings of a prostate nodule and elevated PSA. Delaying further evaluation risks missing or delaying a prostate cancer diagnosis.
✅ Transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP):
Incorrect: TURP is a surgical procedure indicated for severe benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) with significant urinary retention or complications such as bladder stones. It is not appropriate for evaluating a nodule for suspected malignancy or for treating this patient who has moderate BPH.  
❌ Repeat DRE and PSA in three months:
Incorrect: Repeating tests without further diagnostic evaluation would unnecessarily delay this patient’ prostate cancer workup. Findings of a prostate nodule and elevated PSA require immediate investigation with a biopsy.  
❌ Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the prostate:
Incorrect: Multiparametric MRI is a useful tool to detect and localize significant prostate lesions, especially before a targeted biopsy. However, it is not a substitute for a biopsy and is typically used with or after a transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy.

questions.text: A 33-year-old transgender woman presents to the clinic for routine follow-up. Today, the patient feels well without any symptoms. The patient’s close friend was recently diagnosed with a testicular seminoma. The patient is concerned about the risk of testicular cancer and is curious whether screening would be appropriate. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 66/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100% on room air. A thorough history and physical examination are performed. Which of the following findings, if present, would best support screening in this individual?

choices.text: “Bag of worms” palpated in the scrotum
Palpable cord-like structure at the posterosuperior aspect of the testicle

questions.solution:
This 33-year-old transgender woman presents to the clinic to discuss screening for testicular cancer. Of the above answer choices, cryptorchidism (undescended testicle as a child) is the most significant risk factor for developing testicular cancer. Other risk factors include family history and local (e.g. pelvic) radiation.

Testicular cancer most commonly presents in individuals with male reproductive anatomy aged 15-34 years. Patients most commonly present with a painless testicular mass or new symptoms, such as a new scrotal lump, swelling, or pain. History should assess for risk factors like a positive family history or cryptorchidism. On physical examination, assess for a scrotal mass, tenderness, and regional lymphadenopathy.

Screening recommendations for testicular cancer vary by medical organization. Some recommend testicular self-examination for patients with clinical risk factors (e.g., cryptorchidism, family history), while others do not recommend screening for asymptomatic individuals. Patients with concerning symptoms and/or examination findings should undergo further evaluation, including a scrotal ultrasound.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Undescended testicle as a child:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of vasectomy:
Incorrect: A history of vasectomy has not been shown to be a risk factor for developing testicular cancer.
❌ “Bag of worms” palpated in the scrotum:
Incorrect: This finding is typically observed with varicocele, a benign condition that does not increase the risk of testicular cancer. It may be associated with infertility in some cases.
❌ Asymmetric height of the testicles:
Incorrect: A slight difference in testicle height is a common variant and does not indicate pathology.
❌ Palpable cord-like structure at the posterosuperior aspect of the testicle:
Incorrect: A soft, cord-like structure overlying the posterosuperior aspect of the testicle represents the epididymis. The epididymis should be routinely palpated during a testicular self-exam.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the urology clinic for follow-up after a recent orchiectomy for a testicular mass concerning for malignancy. The surgery went well without complications, and the patient has no pain today. The patient has a history of cryptorchidism as a child. Serum studies prior to orchiectomy showed elevated human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) at the upper limit of normal, and normal alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the patient appears well with a well-healing scrotal incision. Pathology of the orchiectomy specimen reveals a well-circumscribed solid tumor with a “fried egg” appearance microscopically. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This young adult male recently underwent orchiectomy for a suspected testicular malignancy. Serum studies show elevated hCG, LDH at the upper limit of normal, and normal AFP. Pathology reveals a well-circumscribed solid tumor with a “fried egg” appearance microscopically. These findings are consistent with a seminoma germ cell tumor.

Testicular cancer most commonly presents as a painless testicular mass in individuals with male reproductive anatomy aged 15-34 years. A scrotal ultrasound often reveals a solid intratesticular mass. Further evaluation includes laboratory studies (e.g., hCG, LDH, AFP) to help confirm the diagnosis, as well as imaging studies (e.g., computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis, chest X-ray) to assess for metastasis. If testicular malignancy is suspected, orchiectomy is performed instead of a testicular biopsy, to avoid the theoretical risk of hematogenous seeding of the tumor. The most common testicular tumors and their associated laboratory and pathologic findings are listed in the table above.

Option Analysis

✅ Seminoma germ cell tumor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Non-seminoma germ cell tumor:
Incorrect: Like seminomas, these tumors may have elevated or normal hCG and LDH levels. However, non-seminoma germ cell tumors will typically cause an elevated AFP, which is not seen in this patient. Pathology would also show other features, such as Schiller-Duval bodies in a yolk sac tumor or syncytiotrophoblasts in choriocarcinoma, which are not described in this case.
❌ Mixed germ cell tumor:
Incorrect: Mixed germ cell tumors may have normal or elevated hCG, LDH, and AFP levels. On pathology, they will show a mixture of seminoma and non-seminoma features. In this case, the pathologic features suggest a seminoma germ cell tumor, as no non-seminoma features are present.
❌ Sex cord/stromal tumor:
Incorrect: Sex cord/stromal tumors present with normal hCG, LDH, and AFP levels, unlike the patient in this vignette. Pathology would demonstrate Leydig or Sertoli cells, which do not appear here.
❌ Testicular lymphoma:
Incorrect: Testicular lymphoma is rare in younger individuals; it is more common in older males (generally in those older than 60 years). It typically does not present with the elevated hCG or AFP seen here. Additionally, testicular lymphoma usually has a more infiltrative or nodular appearance on pathology, which does not match the description of a well-circumscribed solid tumor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine health examination. The patient feels generally well and has no complaints. Medical history is notable for gastroesophageal reflux disease managed with pantoprazole. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is normal. The patient is interested in being tested for CA-125 because a friend who was recently diagnosed with ovarian cancer was found positive for this marker. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Screening with CA-125 for ovarian cancer is recommended
Screening with CA-125 and transvaginal ultrasound for ovarian cancer is recommended
CA-125 is useful only for screening premenopausal women
CA-125 is used in case of equivocal results on fine-needle biopsy for confirmation
CA-125 should be used for follow-up of post-treatment surveillance

questions.solution:
Ovarian cancer is the 2nd most common gynecologic malignancy in developed countries and 3rd in developing countries (cervical cancer is most common). In the United States, ovarian cancer is the most common cause of gynecologic cancer death. Currently, no screening methods have been found to reduce mortality. Serum cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) is the most extensively used laboratory test for the early detection of ovarian cancer. Unfortunately, this test has many shortcomings, as it may be elevated in healthy individuals and in many benign conditions, it fluctuates during menstruation, it increases with age, and it can vary with ethnicity and smoking status. CA-125 serial measurements are instead an important component of the follow-up of post-treatment surveillance.

The current recommendation of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists are as follows:    

Asymptomatic woman at any age - Screening with CA-125 alone or in combination with transvaginal ultrasound is not recommended and increases the risk of invasive tests.    

Premenopausal women with very high levels of CA-125 OR ascites OR signs of distal metastases should be referred to a gynecologic oncologist.    

Postmenopausal women with elevated levels of CA-125 OR nodular/fixed pelvic mass OR ascites OR signs of distal metastases should be referred to a gynecologic oncologist.  

Women who are considered high risk for developing ovarian cancer such as those with a BRCA mutation or Lynch syndrome should be referred to genetic counseling.   

Option Analysis

❌ Screening with CA-125 for ovarian cancer is recommended:
Incorrect: Screening with CA-125 in asymptomatic women is not recommended due to high rates of false-positive results and increasing the risk for invasive testing.
❌ Screening with CA-125 and transvaginal ultrasound for ovarian cancer is recommended:
Incorrect: Screening with CA-125 and transvaginal ultrasound alone or in combination in asymptomatic women is not recommended due to high rates of false-positive results and increasing the risk for invasive testing.
❌ CA-125 is useful only for screening premenopausal women:
Incorrect: Screening with CA-125 in asymptomatic women is not recommended due to high rates of false-positive results and increasing the risk for invasive testing. In general, the specificity of CA-125 in asymptomatic premenopausal women is particularly low compared to postmenopausal women because it is often elevated in many benign conditions which are common in reproductive-age patients.
❌ CA-125 is used in case of equivocal results on fine-needle biopsy for confirmation:
Incorrect: Fine-needle biopsy is not used for the diagnosis of ovarian cancer due to increased risk for seeding. Diagnosis is made with surgery.
✅ CA-125 should be used for follow-up of post-treatment surveillance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0010, comes to her obstetrician for follow-up following spontaneous abortion. The patient developed vaginal bleeding with passage of products of conception at 16 weeks gestation two months ago. She underwent treatment with misoprostol, and her vaginal bleeding stopped after a few days. The patient feels well except for an occasional cough. She states she is currently in her menstrual cycle. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg. Dry rales are heard diffusely throughout the bilateral lungs. Beta human chorionic gonadotropin levels are 45,000 mIU/ml. The chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action for the most appropriate medication to manage this patient’s condition?
 

Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Creation of free radicals that unwind DNA
Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogs into DNA
Formation of cross-links between strands of DNA

questions.solution:
The patient has an elevated chorionic gonadotropin level, vaginal bleeding, cough, and evidence of pulmonary metastases (cannonballs on chest x-ray). Together, these findings are suggestive of systemic choriocarcinoma following spontaneous abortion. The first-line treatment for gestationally derived choriocarcinoma is methotrexate.

Dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) normally converts dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF), which provides methyl groups necessary for the synthesis of dTMP from dUMP and for subsequent purine synthesis. Methotrexate, a folic acid analog, has a higher affinity for DHFR than DHF  and binds to irreversibly inhibits this enzyme. THF is also involved in the synthesis of purines and amino acids. The result is a net decrease in the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins resulting in inhibition of cell division.

Methotrexate can treat leukemia, especially acute lymphoblastic leukemia, primary CNS lymphoma and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, solid tumors like breast cancer, and head, neck, and bladder cancer. It is the medication of choice for early unruptured ectopic pregnancy and choriocarcinoma, a germ cell tumor. Other indications for its use include rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, and dermatomyositis.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of beta-tubulin polymerization  :
Incorrect: Vincristine inhibits beta-tubulin polymerization, which inhibits the formation of the essential microtubules for cell division. It is indicated in the management of solid tumors, leukemias, Hodgkin, and non-Hodgkin lymphomas.  
❌ Creation of free radicals that unwind DNA  :
Incorrect: The creation of free radicals that cause breaks in DNA is the mechanism by which anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) treat solid tumors, leukemias, and lymphomas, but not choriocarcinomas.  
✅ Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogs into DNA  :
Incorrect: Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogs into DNA is the mechanism of several widely used antineoplastic agents, such as 5-fluorouracil. It is not the first-line treatment option for choriocarcinoma.  
❌ Formation of cross-links between strands of DNA  :
Incorrect: Formation of cross-links between strands of DNA and subsequent inhibition of DNA replication is the mechanism of action of several alkylating agents (e.g., busulfan, cyclophosphamide) and platinum-based chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., cisplatin, carboplatin). These agents are indicated in the treatment of solid tumors, leukemias, and lymphomas but are not the first-line treatment option for choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 59-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to her gynecologist with a 3-month history of increased abdominal girth, pelvic pressure, pelvic pain, anorexia, and fatigue. She does not have abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, vaginal discharge, change in urination, or change in bowel habits. Her medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension controlled with enalapril and lovastatin. Her family history is significant for a parent with colon cancer. Temperature is 37.2 °C (98.9 °F), heart rate is 74 beats per minute, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/80 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals distension and diffuse mild tenderness without rebound. A fluid wave and shifting dullness are present. Pelvic examination reveals a 10 cm fixed right sided irregular mass. Which of the following historical elements, if present, would be consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Family history of a sister with cervical cancer
History of 3 spontaneous normal vaginal deliveries

questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient presents with increased abdominal girth, pelvic pressure and pain, and physical examination findings of an irregular, fixed pelvic mass and ascites, which supports a diagnosis of ovarian cancer. Early satiety is a symptom frequently experienced by patients with ovarian cancer.

Patients with epithelial ovarian cancer can present with a broad spectrum of vague non-specific symptoms that can easily be dismissed. Early satiety is a symptom that should be further investigated. Compression of the stomach from metastases to the upper abdomen or from associated ascites can reduce gastric capacity and lead to the feeling of fullness after eating only a small amount of food. In addition, small bowel adhesions and metastases producing varying levels of bowel obstruction and interfering with normal gastrointestinal mobility and function can further contribute to this sensation.

Given this patient’s history and physical exam findings, there is a high likelihood of finding advanced stage III or IV cancer at the time of surgical exploration. Unfortunately, patients with epithelial ovarian cancer often present at an advanced stage. Other symptoms that may be present include constipation, urinary frequency, dyspnea, and weight loss. Vaginal bleeding, when present, may reflect uterine metastases or the presence of a hormonally active ovarian tumor.

Several risk factors are known to either increase or decrease the chances of developing epithelial ovarian cancer. Those that heighten risk include older age, inherited mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes, Lynch syndrome type II, nulliparity, infertility, early menarche, and late menopause. Conversely, those that lower risk include oral contraceptive use, childbirth, breastfeeding, and undergoing bilateral tubal ligation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of a sister with cervical cancer:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has ovarian cancer. Most cases of ovarian cancer are sporadic and not inherited, even in patients with a strong family history. Hereditary ovarian cancer can be site-specific, part of breast-ovarian cancer syndrome, or connected to Lynch syndrome type II.  
❌ History of 3 spontaneous normal vaginal deliveries:
Incorrect: Increasing parity has been shown to protect against ovarian cancer as it results in a decrease in incessant ovulation, which is thought to be a possible cause of ovarian cancer. Women who have had one or more full-term pregnancies have a lower risk of developing ovarian cancer compared to nulliparous women.  
❌ History of bilateral tubal ligation:
Incorrect: Bilateral tubal ligation has been associated with a decreased relative risk of ovarian cancer.
❌ History of cigarette smoking:
Incorrect: This patient likely has an advanced stage of the most common epithelial tumor of the ovaries, serous cystadenocarcinoma, for which, the risk is not increased by cigarette smoking.  
✅ History of early satiety:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office for a routine examination. She is asymptomatic and has no concerns. Past medical history is significant for tobacco use. She has no history of abnormal pap smears. Vital signs are within normal limits. Chaperoned examination of the vulva reveals a 2 cm erythematous lesion with ill-defined borders on the posterior right labia majora that was not present when she had an IUD placed 6 months ago. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s vulvar lesion is concerning for vulvar cancer based on the exam findings of color change, ill-defined borders, and rapid growth. The best next step in management is to perform a full-thickness skin biopsy such as a punch biopsy, to get a pathological diagnosis. Other concerning findings for malignancy that can be seen with vulvar lesions include raised or ulcerative lesions and findings of atypical vascular patterns. 

Squamous cell vulvar cancer is the most common type of vulvar cancer. Lesions are commonly found on the posterior two-thirds of either labia majora. Squamous cell vulvar cancer can have varied clinical findings. Lesions can be raised or flat with variable coloration from white to erythematous. Findings from Colposcopy may include leukoplakia, hyperpigmentation or erythema, atypical vascular patterns with friability, and ulcerative or warty lesions. Vulvar colposcopy is often performed to help define the extent of the vulvar lesion, to aid in where biopsies are performed, and in conjunction with surgical excision to help ensure negative margins.

Lesions that have features concerning for squamous cell cancer (SCC) should be biopsied. Pathologic findings consistent with SCC include cytologic atypia through the full thickness of the epithelium and invading into the dermis. It is important to note the anatomical position of the lesion with respect to the midline and distance from the vaginal introitus, as this information is critical in planning surgery. 

Vulvar melanoma is a rare form of vulvar cancer that usually presents as a pigmented lesion, with one or more abnormal ABCDEs findings: asymmetry; irregular, ragged, or notched borders; brown or black coloration or pink, red, white, or blue; diameter greater than 6 millimeters; change in size, shape, or color. Biopsy will show infiltration by atypical melanocytes and positive staining for melanoma-specific antigen.    

Option Analysis

✅ Punch biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Reassurance:
Incorrect: Reassurance is appropriate for benign appearing lesions that do not have any features that are concerning for malignancy. However, the erythematous color, ill-defined borders, and rapid growth over 6 months of this lesion are concerning for malignancy and a punch biopsy is indicated. 
❌ Wide local excision:
Incorrect: Wide local excision is appropriate for lesions that already have a pathologic diagnosis from prior vulvar biopsy and show HSIL with suspicion for underlying cancer; VIN, differentiated type, squamous cell carcinoma, or vulvar melanoma. This patient does not yet have a diagnosis; therefore, a punch biopsy is the appropriate next step to make a diagnosis. 
❌ Treatment with topical trichloroacetic acid (TCA):
Incorrect: Topical TCA is appropriate first line treatment for lesions that are consistent with condylomata acuminate in a premenopausal patient; this patient has features concerning for malignancy and destruction prior to making a diagnosis with a punch biopsy is not appropriate. 
❌ Laser ablation:
Incorrect: Laser ablation is appropriate for lesions that are confirmed HSIL from prior biopsy and do not have findings suspicious for underlying cancer. This patient has not yet had a tissue diagnosis, making punch biopsy the best next step in management.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office for evaluation of a new vulvar lesion that the patient felt while showering. The patient describes the lesion as raised with a slightly rough texture. Past medical history is significant for several prior abnormal pap smears in the past that required cervical colposcopy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Chaperoned examination of the vulva reveals a singular 0.5 cm raised, slightly hypopigmented lesion on the perineal body. A punch biopsy reveals cytologic atypia in two-thirds of the epithelium, without invasion, with extension to the biopsy margins. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s examination and biopsy results are consistent with a vulvar high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). Treatment options for HSIL include topical therapies, wide local excision, and laser ablation. The goal of a wide local excision is removal of the entire lesion with negative margins.

HSILs are high-grade, HPV-related lesions. On physical exam, these lesions are typically localized with a raised, slightly rough texture. They are generally found on the posterior, hairless area of the vulva and perineal body, but can occur anywhere. A biopsy is required to make the diagnosis and exclude cancer. Biopsy results will show cytologic atypia from two-thirds to full thickness of the epithelium, without invasion.

High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions are considered pre-cancerous and can progress to malignancy if left untreated. Excision is typically the preferred treatment. Ablation can be used to treat multifocal disease and lesions on the clitoris, urethra, anus or vaginal introitus. Imiquimod is an immune-modifying topical therapy that enhances immunity to HPV and is a good option for patients with a suitable risk profile (no evidence of invasive disease or risk factors for invasive disease) who prefer to avoid a procedure. Due to the risk of recurrence of HSIL, long-term follow-up is needed after treatment. Routine cervical cancer screening is also important in patients with vulvar HSIL, as there is a high chance of coexisting, HPV-related cervical lesions.

Option Analysis

✅ Wide local excision:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Topical high potency corticosteroid ointment:
Incorrect: Topical high potency corticosteroid ointment is an appropriate treatment for vulvar skin disorders such as lichen sclerosis and lichen planus. This patient’s biopsy is consistent with a vulvar high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion; therefore, destruction or removal is required.
❌ Vaginal estrogen cream:
Incorrect: Vaginal estrogen cream is appropriate treatment for vulvovaginal atrophy in postmenopausal patients or in premenopausal women in the postpartum period. This patient’s biopsy findings are consistent with a vulvar high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion that requires destruction, or removal.
❌ Reassurance:
Incorrect: Reassurance is appropriate treatment for benign vulvar lesions such as a small epidermal inclusion cyst. This patient’s cytologic atypia on biopsy is consistent with HGSIL which requires further treatment.
❌ Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine:
Incorrect: The widespread administration of the HPV vaccine has reduced the incidence of vulvar dysplasia; however, it is designed to be used as a prophylactic measure and not as a treatment for HPV-related lesions.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents for a routine physical. She has regular menstrual periods and is sexually active. Past medical history includes all normal cervical cytology screening. She smokes 5 to 10 cigarettes per week and consumes 1 to 3 alcoholic beverages most weekend evenings. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mmHg. The pelvic exam is unremarkable, with a normal appearing cervix, vagina, and vulva. A sample is taken for cervical cytology screening and human papillomavirus (HPV) testing. The results show HPV-negative atypical squamous cells, cannot exclude high-grade lesions (ASC-H). Which of the following factors would most significantly increase this patient’s risk of grade 3 cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 3) and the need for immediate treatment?

choices.text: History of > 3 sex partners within the last 6 months

questions.solution:
The results of this patient's cervical cytology screening and human papillomavirus (HPV) testing show HPV-negative atypical squamous cells, cannot exclude high-grade lesions (ASC-H). Immediate treatment is recommended when patients have CIN 3 or worse (e.g., adenocarcinoma in situ, invasive cervical cancer) on a cervical biopsy (CIN3+). Factors that most increase a patient’s immediate risk of CIN3+ include current and previous high-grade or HPV-positive screening results, advanced age, and immunocompromise. A history of a solid organ transplant, use of immunosuppressive medications, or HIV infection indicates immunocompromise, which significantly increases a person’s immediate risk of CIN3+ and their need for immediate treatment.       

Cervical cancer screening involves cervical cytology (i.e. the microscopic examination of individual cells for dysplasia) and testing patients for the presence of high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) subtypes. When these initial screening tests come back abnormal, the next step for patients who are at least 25 years old is to calculate their risk of current CIN3+ using an online tool from the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP). The tool uses the patient’s age, current and previous cytology and HPV results, and whether they are immunocompromised or have had a hysterectomy. Patients with an immediate risk of CIN3+ that is > 4% require either further evaluation with colposcopy and biopsies or, in some cases when the risk is extremely high, immediate treatment.   

Option Analysis

✅ History of organ transplant:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ History of cervical chlamydia :
Incorrect: A history of a sexually transmitted infection (STI) does increase the risk of HPV. However, it does not increase the risk of severe dysplasia (the indication for immediate treatment) beyond the risks associated with an HPV infection, unlike immunosuppression – which does. 
❌ History of > 3 sex partners within the last 6 months:
Incorrect: Multiple sex partners does increase the risk of HPV. However, it does not increase the risk of severe dysplasia (the indication for immediate treatment) beyond the risk associated with an HPV infection, unlike immunosuppression – which does. 
❌ Pregnancy:
Incorrect: Pregnancy does not increase the risk of severe dysplasia, which is the indication for immediate treatment. Knowing a patient’s pregnancy status is important because it affects management when screening results are abnormal. 
❌ Heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB):
Incorrect: Heavy but regular menstrual bleeding is not typically a symptom of cervical dysplasia. Irregular bleeding, especially bleeding that occurs after cervical contact, is a more concerning finding that warrants further evaluation. However, the need for immediate treatment is based on the patient’s risk of currently having severe dysplasia, which is not affected by the presence or absence of HMB.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office with daily light vaginal bleeding for the past month. The patient’s last menstrual period was 3 years ago. Past medical history is significant for menarche at age 14, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), uterine fibroids, and heterozygous factor V Leiden mutation. The patient does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. A chaperoned pelvic examination reveals a normal-sized uterus, normal adnexa, and a small amount of blood at the cervical os. An endometrial biopsy shows crowded endometrial glands with solid components, marked nuclear atypia, and significant glandular irregularities. Which of the following risk factors most significantly contributes to this patient’s likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has postmenopausal bleeding and an endometrial biopsy consistent with endometrial cancer. In individuals with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), there is unopposed estrogen exposure from chronic estrogen production without ovulation. This leads to an increased risk of developing endometrial cancer.

Unopposed estrogen exposure is a major risk factor for the development of endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) and endometrial cancer. Unopposed estrogen can be endogenous or exogenous. Endogenous unopposed estrogen may result from chronic anovulation, as seen in PCOS, or from peripheral conversion of androgens to estrone in adipose tissue, as seen in obesity. Exogenous unopposed estrogen can occur in patients using estrogen therapy without progesterone, which is not recommended in those with a uterus.

Additional risk factors for the development of endometrial cancer include nulliparity, early menarche (<12 years of age), late menopause, personal or family history of Lynch syndrome, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Polycystic ovary syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Age of menarche:
Incorrect: The patient was 14 years old at menarche, which falls within the normal range. Early menarche (< 12 years old) is a risk factor for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia and endometrial cancer.
❌ Age of menopause:
Incorrect: The patient’s last menstrual period was at age 50, and the average age of menopause is 51.4 years. Late menopause would be a risk factor for developing endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia and endometrial cancer.
❌ Uterine fibroids:
Incorrect: Uterine fibroids can cause abnormal uterine bleeding in premenopausal patients. However, fibroids are not a risk factor for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia and endometrial cancer.
❌ Heterozygous factor V Leiden mutation:
Incorrect: Factor V Leiden mutation increases the risk of thrombosis. If a patient with factor V Leiden is on an anticoagulant, that can be a cause of uterine bleeding. However, it is not associated with endometrial cancer.
